grounding: Germ cells are the only cell type that is capable of transmitting genetic information to the next generation, which has enabled the continuation of multicellular life for the last 1.5 billion years. Surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms supporting the germline's remarkable ability to continue in this eternal cycle, termed germline immortality. Even unicellular organisms age at a cellular level, demonstrating that cellular aging is inevitable. Extensive studies in yeast have established the framework of how asymmetric cell division and gametogenesis may contribute to the resetting of cellular age. This review examines the mechanisms of germline immortality—how germline cells reset the aging of cells—drawing a parallel between yeast and multicellular organisms.
generated_text: Asymmetric stem cell division is a fundamental process that contributes to germline immortality by ensuring the maintenance of a pristine genetic lineage across generations. This study explores the mechanisms by which asymmetric division preserves cellular youthfulness, focusing on the role of ribosomal DNA (rDNA) in aging and cellular senescence. We examine how differential distribution of cellular components during division influences the longevity of germline cells, contrasting with somatic cell aging. Our findings suggest that the selective retention of intact rDNA copies in germline cells is crucial for sustaining their immortality. Understanding these processes provides insights into the molecular underpinnings of aging and potential interventions to extend cellular lifespan.
